intro: Guazuma ulmifolia var. tomentosa, commonly known as the wooly guazuma, is a deciduous tree native to Central and South America. It belongs to the family Sapotaceae and is characterized by its smooth, gray bark and opposite, ovate leaves with a dense, woolly pubescence on the underside. The tree produces small, yellowish-green flowers that are clustered in panicles, followed by woody, spherical fruits containing a single, large, smooth-seeded pulp. It is often found in tropical and subtropical regions, growing in a variety of soil types and showing some tolerance to drought conditions.
